practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: I want you to build small, throwaway apps that focus purely on getting data from a view to a template. Don't worry about the database yet; just master the routing and the request-response cycle.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Building simple functional views and mapping them to unique URLs.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Experimenting with Django template tags to display dynamic dummy data.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Creating a new view and linking it to a template via a URL.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Passing complex dictionary structures through context and iterating them in templates without syntax errors.

objective: Successfully route 5 different URLs to 5 unique views.
Display data from a view context in a template using logic tags.
subjective: Feeling less confused by the directory structure.
Visualizing the path of a request from browser to view.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: Now you need to get your hands dirty with the ORM. You'll spend this time defining models and using Django's built-in forms to let users actually interact with your database.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Defining models and performing CRUD operations via the Django shell and admin panel.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Building ModelForms and rendering them in templates to handle user input.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Running migrations and adding basic fields to a model.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Handling ForeignKey relationships and performing multi-table queries with the ORM.

objective: Create a functional create/update form that saves data to the DB.
Query a specific set of objects using filters in the Django shell.
subjective: Confidence in managing database migrations without breaking the app.
Seeing the power of the ORM instead of manual SQL.

practice_cycles.short_explanation_for_cycle: This is where it comes together. You'll build a cohesive app that requires users to log in, and you'll start looking at how to protect specific parts of your site.

weekly_loop.primary_activity: Integrating Django’s built-in authentication system for login/logout and restricted views.
weekly_loop.secondary_activity: Refactoring code into Class-Based Views (CBVs) to reduce boilerplate.

difficulty_profile.comfortable: Using login_required decorators on simple function views.
difficulty_profile.challenging: Overriding default authentication templates or extending the User model.

objective: A working application with at least two user roles (e.g., staff vs regular user).
Transitioning at least 3 views from functions to CBVs.
subjective: Feeling like the 'Django way' of doing things is becoming intuitive.
Reduced reliance on external tutorials for basic logic setup.

objective: Time taken to build a standard CRUD feature from scratch.
Number of logic bugs encountered per new feature.
Correct use of Django conventions (PEP8, naming).
subjective: Level of comfort when reading Django documentation.
Confidence in explaining the MTV flow to someone else.
Degree of 'magic' felt (aiming for less magic, more understanding).

architect_notes: Django has a steep learning curve due to 'magic' behind the scenes; don't rush into DRF before the core is solid.
The 8-hour window is tight; stick to 2-hour blocks to maintain focus.
Avoid the temptation to use complex third-party packages until the core components are mastered.

details.reason: User initiated a new learning session.

timeline.title: Initial Practice Strategy Created
timeline.summary: Initial practice strategy created for ['Learn Django'].

details.reason: Sufficient information provided to create initial practice system.
